results.summary: Tributes are paid to a 16-year-old schoolgirl who was stabbed to death on a bus in Birmingham.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/71badfd7-5876-7a47-9522-b6b135f607d4"><image id="66252167"/><paragraph role="introduction">Tributes have been paid to a 16-year-old schoolgirl who was stabbed to death on a bus in Birmingham.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina Edkins died on the way to Leasowes High School in Halesowen in what police described as a seemingly random attack.</paragraph><paragraph>A 22-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder.</paragraph><paragraph>Floral tributes were laid near to the spot on Hagley Road where Christina died, while friends described her as a caring, fun-loving person.</paragraph><paragraph>A card on one bunch of roses read: "Christina a truly lovely young girl. We'll miss you. Rest in peace angel. Cass and Ben".</paragraph><paragraph>Another card read: "To Christina. We will miss you loads. You were a beautiful girl and a bundle of joy. Rest in peace cutey. Lots of love Ryan and Dale xxx".</paragraph><paragraph>Laura Bishop, 16, said Christina had only celebrated her sixteenth birthday last week.</paragraph><crosshead>Support for pupils</crosshead><paragraph>She said: "She loved to party. She was the most amazing person. No one hated her, there was nothing to hate.</paragraph><paragraph>"We were all having a laugh last Saturday. It's like ripped something out of you. She's been 16 for one week."</paragraph><paragraph>Laura said she had known Christina and her family for about eight years and she could only imagine what they were going through.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="66267509">    <caption>Friends paid tribute to Christina Edkins, who they described as a fun-loving and caring girl</caption>  </video><paragraph>Katie Howells, 15, said many of Christina's friends felt "lost".</paragraph><paragraph>She said: "You can't take someone's best friend, someone's daughter, someone's sister. Why would you do that?"</paragraph><paragraph>Some friends said they were planning to release balloons in her memory.</paragraph><paragraph>Police said her family, who are being supported by specially trained officers, had been left "distressed and distraught".</paragraph><paragraph>Neil Shaw, the head teacher at Christina's school, said both friends and family were "deeply saddened" by her death.</paragraph><paragraph>"Christina was a bright and popular student much loved by staff and students alike," he said.</paragraph><paragraph>"The school is working closely with the police and a team of counsellors to provide support to our pupils and staff."</paragraph><paragraph>The Archbishop of Birmingham, The Most Reverend Bernard Longley, sent his condolences in a message from Rome.</paragraph><paragraph>He said he had been shocked to hear about the "terrible attack" and that his thoughts and prayers were with Christina's family and pupils at Leasowes High School.</paragraph><paragraph>Reverend Mike Rutter, Vicar of St Peter's Church in Lapal, Halesowen, said the church would remain open to people in the community who wanted to pray or light a candle in her memory.</paragraph><paragraph>A Facebook tribute page dedicated to Christina was flooded by messages, one saying her death had left the nation "in shock".</paragraph></body>
